author: galsen19
title: Digitalization of town halls
description: In Senegal,city administrators have great difficulty receiving or recovering their administrative documents in the event of an emergency or in the event of need without having to travel

f6_assessments.q0:
The governmental bureaucratic process in a lot of countries has not kept pace with the modern world and becomes a complete hassle for anyone who needs to interact with it. Asking for the release of a document copy might take a very long time, days, if not weeks. Blockchain is definitely the solution for many of these instances. I greatly appreciate the idea and willingness of the team behind this proposal, to develop a cryptographic system on the Cardano blockchain for the town halls in Senegal. However, I am unsure, since it hasn’t been described in the proposal if the team has actually contacted someone who is in the position to confirm that if they develop this infrastructure, it will also be adopted/implemented by the town halls. Unfortunately, these kind of endeavours are usually not being completed, not because of a lack of genuinely interested and capable individuals, who would be willing to work on a solution, but because the bureaucrats running these places are: 
1. Not willing to change the way they work
If they are
2. then they will be offering the set aside budget (which most of the time is very big) for this task to either the best bidder or to a “friend’s” company, as they would, of course, be incentivised to do so.
So this is where my concern lies. If the team behind the project does indeed finish the task, and since they seem willing and capable, I do not doubt that, but if they do, will it actually be implemented in the town halls in Senegal?
Maybe for this challenge, this concern does not play such an important role and constitutes mostly a bit of advice to the proposing team. Especially since I consider the idea behind the project to be at least a very good experiment that could possibly offer unexpected results in the future. At the same time, I consider it to have a positive impact on the ecosystem through the development of a new infrastructure and as such, I will rate it with 4.
f6_assessments.q1:
I am not a developer, but I have been monitoring the development of numerous projects, and as such, I find the timeline and budget (constrained for this challenge at $5000) of this proposal to be a bit too low to actually achieve the desired results. I can see that the student(s) involved in this project are dedicated and imagine that they would finish their work, even if it were to take longer than anticipated and without asking for additional pay. 
What I think is an important missing section of the proposal is the team description, there is a short paragraph containing the skills of the team members, but we have no way of verifying those, as there are no names, no external links, no mention of their previous work. I am not sure which of the team members are students and which are experienced professionals in their respective fields. Because of this, I find it difficult to assess the team’s capability in implementing the proposal.
I would also like to add, that the team mentions that they have other proposals in this fund,  and even though it was a requirement when submitting the proposal, the team has not offered any description related to them and/or links to said proposals.
In conclusion, based on the information offered and the questions I am left with after analysing this section, I must say that I am unsure about the successful implementation of the project, and because of this, I will rate it with a 3.
f6_assessments.q2:
The answer to how the project's progress will be tracked is too generalised, to me, it seems it doesn’t offer any particular details, metrics, or solutions. To each of the answers, my question is ”but, how?” For example, the proposal states “Define and respect the deadlines for each defined task.” As such, my question is “How? How will the team define and respect the deadline? And how/where can the community verify if the deadlines are being kept?”
The same applies to the success question. It is also too generalised and somewhat unnecessary, for example, “Don't go over budget” or “Achieve our end goal” are scopes upon which the team has designed their plan and budget, as such, it could be considered a success in regards to proposal writing but not in regards to the project they would be funded for. 
Lastly, unfortunately, I find the auditability section to be lacking too much information to consider it properly auditable and my final score is 2. I hope the team will return to the proposal if not funded in this fund and consider some of the aspects I and probably, other community members have suggested and introduce those in their proposal and resubmit it.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer identified as a student themselves, which aligns very slightly with the proposal. In general, the proposal aims to bring senegales town hall records to blockchain, which would have a very big impact indeed, so I am giving some stars for impact. However, it is clear to me that the intended impact area for this Campaign is supposed to be students as well, and this proposal really has nothing to do with Students at all.
f6_assessments.q1: This proposal apparently seeks to transform an entire country-wide government agency, and to do it with $5,000 and one new computer. Nothing about that makes sense.  They have one "Developer" on the team, but no details are given about their blockchain experience. They also plan to "Call on" other developers in the community, but apparently do not have any budget to pay them.  The timeline and budget areas include some generalities that could apply to nearly any project, but no real details at all. There is no evidence that the proposer understands what they plan to undertake. The question of whether Senegalese Town Halls are even willing to put all their records on the blockchain isn't even mentioned. I don't see anything feasible about this project, unfortunately.
f6_assessments.q2:
The main auditability metric is "Achieve our end goal" which I guess could be said for any project -- which is to say, it says nothing at all. We need quantifiable details of what would be achieved. How any records on the blockchain? How many people onboarded? How do people access their records once they are on the blockchain? 
This project is a nice idea, and is a good example of where Cardano would like to go! I don't think think proposer has a good idea about how this works yet. A good first step might be a proposal for a research project, networking with others who are doing this type of work, and developing a more detailed plan with clear steps along the way. I think this kind of research work could be funded through project catalyst if presented well.

f6_assessments.q0:
I might be misinterpreting the proposal or there has been some issue with translating the document to English, but from my (possibly faulty) understanding, this proposal is about creating an informatic system on the Cardano Blockchain. In order for people to have easy access to administrative documents from everywhere in the world. How is this relevant to the challenge? Well, the proposal comes from a student entrepreneur, the target group of this challenge setting. 
 The proposer mentions that the team aims to improve government efficiency by integrating all of the government transaction to the Cardano Blockchain, and expanding it to other governments. Here I would like to have had further clarifications on what governments the proposer means to focus on (Senegalese government? Regional or national?). Maybe also some further examples of how the team plans to collaborate with these institutions and expand their operation to other governments. 
 In my experience working with educational institutions (as a researcher), it might be challenging to formalize a partnership that will be incorporated 100% by the institution. Especially if it is a lesser known actor within the space. And even if they do manage to find a way in, it might possibly take a lot of time to get there. I don’t know if the proposing team already has established a collaboration with the Senegalese government, and I’m happy to acknowledge that I’m wrong in raising concerns for the scalability of the project.  It is somewhat clear what the proposer intends to do, but I would’ve liked to see more detail in ’how’ the team means to execute their solution to the problem. It would also be highly beneficial to include more details on what part of the Cardano ecosystem is intended to be used to secure these documents. Will the project incorporate DIDs or something similar? 
Overall, I neither agree or disagree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal includes a 3 month roadmap, split into three phases. It Is mostly centered around web development, training workshops on blockchain, web marketing and social media. The roadmap itself does provide us with some useful information, but it could be expanded upon with adding more information. Apart from in the roadmap and the budget breakdown, there is no mention of organizing events present in the proposal, and that would be valuable information to include as part of the solution to the stated problem (the ’how’). Furthermore, a roadmap is greatly benefitted by being paired with the information in the budget breakdown and information about the proposing team, so let’s do that. 

According to the proposal, the team consists of a project manager and a web developer. There is contact information and LinkedIn-profile provided for the project manager, but no mentions of either identity or experience of the web developer. There are mentions of hiring experienced blockchain developers from the Cardano Community, but these does not seem to be included in the budget breakdown (so I’m assuming it is for a later stage of development). The project manager is involved in several other proposals for Fund 9 in a variety of different challenges, working on different projects unrelated to each other. 
As a recurring PA since Fund 6, this leads me to worry a bit about the potential workload that might occur, since the team consists of a small number of people. It would be nice to
Include a paragraph explaining how the team plans to divide the workload if all the proposals are funded. 

Regarding the budget breakdown, I would suggest to add an estimate of the working hours for each person in the team (maybe also add estimations of the hourly wage). With this information, we have access to more information that will help us estimate the total workload needed to finalize this project. In short, who will be working on what section of the project, and is there budget allocations made for this? Where does it fit into the roadmap?   

Any extra information on the development process will be helpful to include. Due to the lack of information provided in the proposal, I disagree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: As stated under ’feasibility’, the roadmap would benefit greatly of including more detail on what the actual tasks during development is. In that way, the listed KPIs for the project would be easier to measure (for example, define and respect the deadlines for each defined task, as stated in the proposal). It is good to see that the team aims to share weekly reports of the development progress with the community, and it would be even better if the proposal would include links to where these reports would be shared. Because as of now, there are no links provided where the community can follow the development progress, apart from the email of the project manager.   When listing measurements of success, I would suggest to specify if ’End goal’ means the finishing of this proposal, or the whole idea of the project. Maybe I am misinterpreting, but as a voter I would find it more clear to know if the proposal means to finish a small part of a larger idea in 3 months, or the whole grand scheme. Conclusively, I disagree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a brilliant idea from a student. It presents a great impact on the society and in fact a whole nation. It addresses this challenge effectively because this is a project from a student. The goal of this challenge is to be able to seed proposals from student entrepreneurs and also provide a network of engineers to help them develop the ideas. This proposal is from a student, it impacts society, they seek the collaborate with engineers in the ecosystem and they seek to also build a network that works on the Cardano blockchain. 
This is great.
f6_assessments.q1:
I think this proposal is too huge for the funds requested. Trying to connect all city town halls in Senegal to a network that will share a lot of data will need a lot of networking and engineering and I don't know if the funds in this challenge can handle such a project.
But apart from this the proposer presents a good plan with a well-elaborated budget. 
The proposer does not include details of the team members which is a requirement in the proposal. 
They proposed that they will contact an engineer from the community to support them and that is good. But I think a step like that should've been taken so that they can include the name and experience of the person(s) in the proposal for easy assessment.
I give 3 because of the relevant information that is missing but I don't in any way doubt the team's ability to deliver.
f6_assessments.q2:
The milestones and timelines can be used to track the progress. The team also indicated that they will present reports to the community. The success metrics are not very elaborate for me. 
I give 4 because if the team works on the success metrics well to include practical and measurable deliverables like eg. people not delaying in getting their birth certs as they used to, this proposal would be excellent and suitable.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal highlights the difficulty that the inhabitants of the country of Senegal have when having to do administrative procedures with personal documents, which can take meaningless periods of time, generating obstacles in the day-to-day life of these people. The solution to this problem, to help municipalities solve their problems, is to develop a system in Cardano’s network, so that each of the inhabitants can receive, from anywhere in the world, the document they need as quickly as possible to their email. I believe that the proposal can become a great idea to implement because, over time, most people will begin to understand that the tools that Cardano offers can generate great changes in people's daily lives. This proposal effectively addresses the challenge, and for this reason, I rate the impact with a score of 5.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal did not provide evidence such as references or links about the whole team to support their experience and skills. It would be nice for voters to add these references because they may be able to validate this information about their experience and skills. The proposal provides a simple but detailed and reasonable budget with a specific amount to be able to carry out the project successfully. The proposer has considered risk relevant to a successful implementation already providing solutions to manage these risks. I expect a successful implementation so I am going to rate feasibility with a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer provides a roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement during 3 months but these could be quite better described. There are also several metrics and KPIs to track the success of the project over the months, looking to respect the deadlines and budget for each defined task and achieving the use of the Cardano blockchain for Senegalese town halls. I rate auditability with a score of 4.

f6_assessments.q0:
I disagree that the proposal could solve the problem it intends to solve.

The proposer intends to build a blockchain-based information system in which the government will store citizen data. In theory, it helps citizens get their data from anywhere, without having to visit their town hall. However, there are a ton of implementation details that need to be sorted out. I’ll get back to what I mean by this in the next section.

The proposer should meet with their town hall first and talk about the bottleneck. Is it really because there is no database and IT infrastructure? If it is, then the question becomes how willing they are to migrate and digitalize. After all, they are the ones who are going to implement the system. We then need to consider how to maintain the IT infrastructure and deal with data security laws. This is a very, very huge project and I am not sure if the proposer knows it.

However, I also want to appreciate the proposer for observing real-world problems and trying to tackle them directly. As a student, that’s a really good skill to have, and this challenge setting is made specifically for ideas like this. I will support the proposer again once the details have been provided clearly and the puzzle pieces are solved.
f6_assessments.q1: As presented, there are many vital details that are missing, which makes it unlikely that the proposal could be implemented successfully. First, the proposer doesn’t have enough developers to build the system within 2 months. The proposer stated that they would include a web developer and experienced blockchain developers from the Cardano community. However, with only 2000 USD allocated, the amount is just too low and the two-month time frame is simply not enough to get the system done. The budget is broken down into four different items, but none of them is further explained. For example, the item "launch event organization" is still too big. Does that include the venue or the food or the speakers? The item "Buy PC Portable" is also not justifiable. What is the laptop even used for? I advise the proposer to be more strict with the budget and give more details on what they are used for by dividing it with the number of hours or the number of people involved. The timeline provided is unrealistic. I would love to be proven wrong, but two months for setting up the blockchain database, designing the UI, writing hundreds and thousands of lines of code, and hosting it on a server is not enough. I understand that the proposer doesn’t come from an IT background, but I hope they will take my advice to extend the development time to a minimum of 6 months. The proposer should also extend the time needed for government partnership (because birocracy is not quick, trust me) and plan on the risk of the town halls not wanting to cooperate (this could be mitigated, again, by reaching out to them directly). Overall, there are just too many holes within the plan that I am not confident in backing it.
f6_assessments.q2:
There was no information that we could use to keep track of the project. While the milestones are obvious; complete development of the system within three months, it is unclear what kind of features will be included in that system. Thus, the milestones are practically nonexistent as there is no clear definition of what the end product is going to look like. Perhaps by giving us a product requirement document, we could at least see whether or not the website developed is the same as expected.

The metrics they used don’t have any objective numbers we could refer to in order for us to see if the system is adopted by the town halls or not. The proposer mentioned that they would make weekly reports, but it wasn’t mentioned how we could publicly access these reports. The proposer could use Github or a Kanban board for those reports and make them publicly available. In the end, it is unfortunate that we can’t measure the proposal’s success or monitor its progress at all.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal will create an information system that will be released on the Cardano blockchain, aiding municipalities in efficiently and effectively solving their challenges. The system will be programmed so that every city resident, no matter where they are in the world, will be able to request their administrative papers and have the option of receiving them in their mailboxes; therefore, the proposal clearly outlines the specific difficulties in an area and, if implemented well, will greatly benefit the local community.
f6_assessments.q1: Regarding viability, I completely agree that the idea has a good possibility of being successful because every detail has been carefully considered and the community is easy to use. This proposal included a monthly objective, however regrettably it wasn't very well explained. All of the budget's components are covered in-depth in the detailed descriptions of the budget items. The team who is proposing this has extensive experience working on project-related tasks. With the aforementioned justifications, I'd state once more that this initiative has a good likelihood of success.
f6_assessments.q2: The team defines success in great depth, providing us with enough of stuff to monitor. Excellent auditability. They also describe the phases in detail, so we know what will happen when and can check to see if things are progressing as planned. This allows us to proceed farther in the monitoring process. Although the roadmap is well-designed, it would be preferable if it were more thoroughly explained. I decided to assign a score of 4 as a consequence.

f6_assessments.q0: When the whole world is digitizing and accepting the digital market it is very sad to see that Senegal city are not adapting to the modernization of the technology. Once everything is digitally stored they will be easily accessible by the user and will reduce human efforts and time to do the same manually and hence this proposal has to be implemented for the betterment of the society in Senegal. The proposer has identified the need for digitizing data for the betterment of society in Senegal city and has porposed a solution for it which is commendable. The key metrics specified in this proposal defines the success of the proposal and is aligned to achieve the goal. The proposal can be scalable to address the future challenges.
f6_assessments.q1: The idea of the proposer is good but has failed to present a working plan to implement the proposal. The proposer has not provided enough information to support their experience required for this proposal. The proposer has not provided evidence by providing several reference links to support their proposal. The budget has been mentioned clearly which is 5000 USD and is very reasonable for this proposal and has also been broken down into identifiable individual units which is reasonable for the completion of the project.  The proposer has mentioned the challenges or difficulties faced during implementation of the proposal and has considered them but overall the plan could have been presented more efficiently with more information in the proposal. Hence I do not agree with the experience and plan presented to be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has not laid out a realistic roadmap with the steps for the completion of the proposal within the specified time and the provided information is not sufficient to audit the progress of the proposal after the funding. The key metrics mentioned in the proposal align with the proposed goal. The proposer has identified the problem but has failed to  provide a solution in detail that addresses the problem. Hence I do not feel the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: As Developed countries and developing countries have made all the govt agencies available through online, it has helped people in great manner where they don't need to run govt offices every often. During such a case , in Senegal people have to wait for more than 24 hrs a day just for small certificate which is very sad to hear , with  proper database management and web tools available the proposer wants his city to get connected via internet ,which reduces people to travel unnecessarily to govt offices hence This proposal effectively addresses the challenge
f6_assessments.q1:
Setting up a website might be easy but achieving all security authorization might be difficult ,since the set up has to be used by government offices it should have high level of security protocols to it , otherwise 3rd party member might steal the data or modify the data accordingly.
The team consist of web developer ,cardano expert and HR member the team wont be sufficient to achieve such a great task, just developing web wont achieve goal here proper database management also should be done regularly.
f6_assessments.q2:
The audit could have been more elaborated regarding which online tools the team will be using to achieve the task, and whether single laptop is sufficient to achieve such a big task,
and how the team will get permission to access government authorized data.
The audit has good timeline goals to be achieved and has simple budget break down idea, it even contains proper key indicators where it can complete its task before the mentioned deadline. with such a big goal ahead ,the information provided might not be sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal identifies a problem within the challenge as it seeks to make access to documents easier by developing a system launched on the Cardano blockchain  network. This project is a good opportunity for scouting by engineers who may want to help in enhancing the technology and scaling it up. The project will also add value to the Cardano ecosystem by organizing training workshops on blockchain to create awareness and increase knowledge of more people.
f6_assessments.q1: There is an indication of a timetable for the completion of the work which spans a period of 3 months. However, the proposer does not clearly identify who will be responsible for what activities. Only the project manager Mady Dia was mentioned as being in charge of measuring the progress of the project.
f6_assessments.q2: Although the proposal includes milestones for which progress can be assessed, the key performance indicators are not well thought out and are not indicators at all. Also the description of the target problem cannot be measured against successes. For instance, one success listed is to not go over the budget. This does not fit as an outcome of the described challenge of making retrieval of documents more convenient.

f6_assessments.q0:
given the profile of the proposer, I believe that this proposal is well within the alignment of this challenge setting.he is a student trying to digitize processes in his municipality across various levels in his country. I applaud the student for having such an ambitious ambition, and the impact to the cardano blockchain is clear: by getting cardano to power government/public processes, more people will understand the value that cardano can bring to the table, and hopefully eventually, be more participative in the ecosystem. the solution while straightfoward, is a clear need within the country as the author elaborates context on why he thinks this is important - currently reproducing a birth certificate takes more than 24 hours. if this can be successfully executed, i can see the solution being scalable, as the proposer intends to stating that he wants to expand the project throughout French-speaking Africa later on in future rounds of catalyst funding. this project will be heavily reliant on catalyst funding until it can generate cash flow with these government engagements.

however, i hold my reservations on the likelihood / probability that this project can be executed successfully. the ambition is big and clear, but i note that it might be too big an undertaking for a student. while i am not familiar with local nuances of the Senegal community, it is generally difficult to engage with and change government related processes if you are not in a postiion of power. however, i think it's worth a shot for this student, and will give a rating of 4. the mitigation plans for the risks identified is well within his ability of execution, and while he couldve done more with more funding, i think this is fine for now as a first step.
f6_assessments.q1:
the timeline and milestones were laid out on a monthly basis and is very generic. To further improve the proposal in the future, a lot more details could be added to provide clarity to readers. for example, currently,  I can only hope "Web development" will lead to a finished website at the end of two months, but we have no indication as to the sophistication of the website. is the website just for the project's own marketing and communication for the events and workshops that he intends to have? or does it include a prototype website where government officials can log into to try how the end product will be when linked to the cardano blockchain to execute government processes? the tasks are also not quantified in the timeline - such as training workshops in month 1 and 2. will there be 2 workshops? or 5, or 10? these details will help reader understand the targeted reach the proposer intends to have and the resources needed to execute them.

the same can be said for the budget, where breakdown was only done on a very high level. activities like training workshop, web development, need to be broken down further in to the number of resource working on them so that readers understand if the allocated amount is fair. for example, $2000 for 1 person vs $2000 for 5 people is very different in terms of resource to get work done in a timely manner and if they are paid fairly. without these information, readers will not be able to gauge if the bugeted amount is fair.

the project manager himself is the only listed resource in the proposal, though it was mentioned that there will be a team. we need to know more details of the upcoming team desired to gauge credibility.
f6_assessments.q2:
I would say that the entire auditability section of the project proposal can be much improved on. What would be desired here is to have actual quantitative numbers they can be audited against, like number of workshops conducted, the number of audience targeted for each workshop, number of commits to github repo for web development, and measures of those sort. this is in contrast to what was listed in the proposal, which are:
1. Define and respect the deadlines for each defined task.
2. Make weekly reports to know the progress of the project with the members
3. Set monthly goals for each project member
i appreciate that the proposer did include the item on weekly reports to indicate the frequency of communication, but we need more quantitative details as mentioned above, along with the medium in whcih they plan to communicate these reports with us.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposer is from Senegal, a country in West Africa.  His city administrators and citizens here have significant difficulties in doing paperwork (for instance, people have to stay at the office for 24 hours to get a birth certificate). It's because they don't have computers/ intranet to help their work become automatic and faster. The proposer wants to develop an informatics system on Cardano and "integrate 100% of government transactions into the Cardano". The proposer believes this solution would help Senegalese people get their paperwork automatically via mailboxes. 

I think this is a kind idea, starting from the proposer's willingness to help his city. It addresses the challenge at the point to get more adoption of Cardano and solve problems in the real world. Although I think that this idea is not very realistic to obtain its goals because persuading a government to upload their national data on a blockchain is not very a feasible idea at the moment. As a PA, I still want to encourage this proposer to keep it up. My suggested direction for this proposal is that the proposer should break the plan into small parts, and propose solutions part by part to change the situation. Please keep in mind that the proposal should always consider its impact/ contribution to the Cardano/ Catalyst community and show the strong link between the project with the mission of this community.
f6_assessments.q1:
This proposal has not had a complete team yet. (a) The proposer still wants to call on more developers from the Catalyst community to join. (b) The reference/ profile of the main web developer should be added (c) In the box "Summarize your relevant experience", Catalyst expects to see the experience of the team. I think the proposer misunderstood it as his experience of this city's situation.

To integrate 100% of the government transaction onto Cardano is what the proposer wants to do, but how to do that on Cardano, unfortunately, I cannot find in the proposal. (1) The first obstacle is how to convince a government to share all of their transactions on a blockchain, which is not very easy and feasible to do. Blockchain is still very new to the world, and it is also not yet legal in many countries. (2) Assuming that the government agrees to share their data with Cardano, the proposal lacks a detailed plan about how to build that information system on Cardano technically.

I understand the good intention of the proposer, however, as what is presented in the proposal, the current team and action plan do not have enough ability and capacity to implement this proposal successfully. I hope that the proposer will discuss more how to persuade the government and how to build the system on Cardano.
f6_assessments.q2:
The key metrics to success of this proposal have not been set appropriately. Key metrics/KPIs should be the ruler that defines and measures the desired success of the proposal. For example: Numbers of departments using the new system, numbers of papers sent via emails, numbers of hours have been saved from online registration, etc. 

To "respect the deadlines" or "don't go over budget" is regulations the team can use to keep track of the workload. I hope that my comments help.

f6_assessments.q0:
Obviously this is a good proposal in a country like Senegal to make public administrative procedures more efficient and quick.
However, this is related to national security, so you need to be more careful about the legal issues in your home country, it is better to find a lawyer to ask them for advice and connect with organizations. government is clearer. Because Blockchain technology is new anyway and few governments accept this even though Blockchain technology is very transparent and highly efficient in use, saving a lot of costs. I appreciate your proposal, in line with the challenge posed in this fund.
f6_assessments.q1:
Catalog of the implementation roadmap in just 3 months, in my opinion You should divide into which days are for Web development, which days are held training seminars on Blockchain, which days are web marketing and social media, like so it will be clearer for the route. for example:
  - January 1 - 18: Web development
- Day 19-20: Blockchain seminar
- Days 21 to 30: web marketing and social media
   ... the same for the remaining 2 months.
And another important part after completing the proposal is training for government people so that they can use it more proficiently.
f6_assessments.q2:
The target numbers, the KPIs that you set out to measure the progress and success of the project are presented quite well, easy to understand and transparent.
I really hope this project will be successful, because if successful, it will be a premise for Blockchain to be recognized by governments of other countries and apply Blockchain in public administration, even apply Blockchain in voting. voting, because it will be more transparent and reliable than voting on other centralized applications.

f6_assessments.q0:
Proposer is a student entrepreneur who has identified a systems issue within his local government pertaining to birth certificates. As he mentioned most City/Town Halls in his area lack the proper technology to store, retrieve and distribute said government issued document. 

What would make this proposal interesting is if it is mentioned in detail on how the solution will work in a step-by-step manner. As student I don’t expect a deep explanation on how the tech will work but at least a glimpse on the factors that will heavily impact this project. 

Proposer mentioned that halls doesn’t have database nor intranet but does this mean they have at least computer workstations and internet for government employees? I find this necessary to run any 3rd party solutions. Presenting a problem and solution requires holistic understanding of the situation.

I would have loved it if more details were provided on what the current process of the document issuance and storage looks like, such as:

•	Are these all done manually? 
•	Photocopied? Type-written?
•	Digitally stored in personal workstations or still physical stored in file-cabinets?


As for the solution itself, here are my thoughts: 

•	You’ve expressed that solution is a system that is accessible anywhere in the world and request can be made without physical appearance. This begs the question on how identity will be verified before issuance for such sensitive documents.
•	It was mentioned that integrating 100% of government transactions into Cardano Blockchain with “Gal’Sen” yet no further details on what these transactions will be and what role this so-called start-up will play in the success of the project.
•	You haven’t painted a clear picture on what the solution looks like. Will this be a web-based app and documents will be stored as NFTs? What’s the request submission and request delivery/completion look like? 

Also, I find that risk listed lacks research. Not only that you need the government to agree and partner with your project but also secure the right people to develop.

While proposal address the challenge to encourage students to cultivate ideas and connect with engineering resources in our space it still needs refinement on what the problem entices and how and what the solution would be on its maturity.
f6_assessments.q1:
We don’t expect proposers on this challenge to have a team/implementor readily available. Having that said knowing what type of resource or skills is required is still a must. As an idea creator / proposer or let’s say a visionary you are burdened with the responsibility to have good foundational know how on variety of knowledge/practices. I don’t doubt that proposer has put effort in nourishing his idea however the proposal itself lacks aspects that would guarantee (at least on some levels) its success. 

Let’s start with the plan details and timeline: 

A sound plan includes a well-thought timeline and series of actions. Simply listing Web Development, Training and Marketing is not enough. Voters would need explicit details on what will be done against a certain period of time and how these actions correlate to the projects goal. As a sample, when it comes to: 

1.	Training workshops on blockchain - Is intended recipients of these trainings, you? Or Town Hall employees?, what outcome do you expect out of these trainings?
2.	Seeking partnership with city halls – how will this be executed? As your proposal heavily depends on their support will a legal expert be onboarded? Or have we secured support from a seated official?

Budget wise, a good breakdown shows amount paid in salary for how long. And specifics on how it will be spent vs market rate. 
•	Web development for $2000 doesn’t provide explanation on what is being paid, is this solely the developers salary, hosting services or possibly research as well? 
•	Event Organization – Maybe provide a list of expenses for this event, are we paying for a host? Event location? Marketing materials? 
•	Budget Limit for this challenge is $5000 and is meant to seed the proposal, so best to rethink on how this is spent properly to make the project sustainable or attractive for further catalyst funding. 

Overall, with the information provided in the proposal’s current state it is difficult to imagine that it will move forward effectively.
f6_assessments.q2:
There’s almost no concrete information on how the public would be able to track and measure the projects progress and even success. A public repository of data or updates is a must for transparency. This can be hosted on any publicly accessible social media platform. This not only help us review your progress vs goals but would also help you as a proposer to engage feedback. 

Keep it mind that Goals needs to be set even before your implementation begins. Goals needs to be as objective as they can be needs to be measurable. Think of it as your “North Star”. 

Usually in corporate setting we call this as KPIs or Key Performance Indicators. Majority of the time these are presented in numbers. Samples are the following: 

•	Number of completed trainings. 
•	Social media engagement (comments, re tweets, replies, posts, etc.)
•	Sprints completed
•	QA Scores 
•	Event Participants 

You’d notice that above samples are concrete and measurable in nature.

solution: Currently in Senegal for a simple reproduction of a birth certificate at the level of any municipality you will stay at least more than 24 hours without even having it sometimes more.
experience: After a few visit to senegalese town halls,i was able to find that most town halls do not have a computer database or intranet which would have facilitated their work,which is why the feasibility of the project is more than probable with all the bases that are already present
